title: Why is 'very good' correct but 'very fun' not, in English? - Quora

response.answer_text: I disagree with others here who rigidly assert “fun is not an adjective”. I looked out references when a teacher corrected “so fun” in my daughter’s homework (at the age of 5 or 6); If I recall correctly I found good literary uses of fun as an adjective, up to 2 centuries old.No, you probably wouldn’t say “funner” in a literary work, but would you object to “more fun” - the performance was more fun than last week’s”? Now when you say that, either you’re mentally seeing fun-marks on a scale (adjective) or you’re seeing a bucket of fun (noun) with someone adding another cupful. I suggest the former image is more likely.Yes, I admit “very fun” sounds slightly odd (though not, I think something that can be confidently pronounced incorrect); but “fun is not an adjective” is not the explanation for that. “Very” is a strange word: why can you say “I like you very much” but not “I like you much”? Just custom, really.Language changes and I’m sure “very fun” will sound less odd with time. There’s no real logical reason for avoiding it. UPDATE: I just remembered, back in March 2016 I got a little survey form from Facebook (see attached pic). If anyone knows how to speak good American English, it’s Facebook :) and they definitely approve of “very fun”. Also “somewhat fun” & “slightly fun”. At the time, though, in airing this survey via Twitter, I did suggest noun alternatives:“A metric sh*t-tonne of funA lot of funSome funA little bit of funNo fun at all”. You are welcome to use these, if you’re unhappy with the adjectival forms.

I'm not sure that one can't say 'very fun'. I hear it said - That's a very fun idea. I'd certainly agree that fun can function as an adjective - "That's a fun task" - that's not a fun task.'Very good' is a common expression with several different uses. Very good can mean agreement or acceptance or even "I understand". I don't hear 'very fun' but I do hear 'so fun!' and 'great fun!' and if 'very fun' means much the same as those - it would be understood if one said it even if it's not commonly said.
